questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below :
questions.solution:
The image depicts laryngeal papilloma.

Laryngeal papillomatosis (juvenile papillomatosis)

  • It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is caused by HPV 6 and 11. 
  • Involves supraglottic and glottic regions of larynx.
  • Clinical features:
    • Age 3–5 years
    • Hoarseness or aphonia
    • Respiratory difficulty
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. 
  • Treatment consists of microlaryngoscopy and CO2 laser Excision.

Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis is less common and usually seen in males aged 30-50 years. It is less aggressive and involves the anterior part of the vocal cords. The treatment is the same as juvenile papillomatosis.

questions.text: All are true about the condition that is diagnosed by the given ECG except:

choices.text: Can be seen in asymptomatic individuals
Caused by an abnormal accessory pathway

questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). Its prevalence decreases with age.

The classic ECG features in WPW are as follows:

  • A shortened PR interval (typically <120 ms)
  • A slurring and the slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave)
  • A widened QRS complex (total duration >0.12 seconds)
  • ST-segment–T wave (repolarization) changes, generally directed opposite the major delta wave and QRS complex, reflecting altered depolarization

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

questions.text: Phases of the ventricular muscle action potential are shown below. At which phase is the action potential most dependent on sodium permeability?
questions.solution:
The action potential is most dependant on sodium permeability in phase 0. 

Action potential of myocardium:

  • Phase 0: Depolarisation: Influx of Na+ into myocyte.
  • Phase 1: Early repolarization: Efflux of K+ from myocyte.
  • Phase 2: Plateau: Ca2+ enters myocardial cells via voltage regulated L-type Ca2+ channels.
  • Phase 3: Repolarisation: Efflux of K+.
  • Phase 4: Restoration of RMP: Restoration of Na+ and K+ by Na-K ATPase.

questions.text: The following instrument is commonly used in_______
questions.solution:
The image shown is the 18 G Tuohy needle, which is used in epidural anesthesia.

Identification points:

  • It has a blunt, curved tip (Huber tip) that helps to prevent accidental dural puncture.
  • The needle shaft is marked in 1-cm intervals so that the depth of insertion can be identified.

Epidural anesthesia set with Touhy's needle and epidural catheter.

Other epidural needles: Crawford needle (straight needles without a curved tip): has a greater incidence of dural puncture.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient comes to the OPD with a history significant for a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as done in the image given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing 4 episodes of depression and 2 episodes of mania within 1 year, points towards a diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder. 

It is diagnosed when the patient has 4 or more episodes of depression and/or mania or hypomania within one year. There must be less than 2 weeks of normalcy between the episodes or an immediate shift between the symptoms with no intervening normal mood.

Risk factors:

  • Female patients
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alcoholism or substance abuse
  • Antidepressants (if used without mood stabilizers)
  • Cyclothymia
  • Bipolar II disorder

The drug of choice for rapid cycling disorder is valproate. 

Note: If the phases of mania and depression alternate very rapidly in a matter of hours or days then the condition is known as ultra-rapid cycling disorder.

questions.text: The ECG of a patient as given below is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The above ECG rhythm strip shows 1st degree AV Block.

The following features of this ECG support the diagnosis:

  • The P wave precedes each and every QRS complex
  • PR interval is prolonged
  • The PR interval is constant in every beat

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: Identify the vessel marked in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the MR angiography of cerebral circulation. The structure marked is the anterior cerebral artery which is a branch of the internal carotid artery.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: Given below is an image of a patient with fever and rash. When is the spread of this disease the maximum?

choices.text: Just before and after the onset of rash
One week before onset of rash

questions.solution:
The image depicts the rash of chickenpox, as different stages of the rash can be seen at one time. The communicable period of chickenpox is 2 days before and 5 days after the onset of rash.

Related Pearl: Period of communicability of important diseases

  • Chicken pox – 1-2 days before to 4-5 days after appearance of rash
  • Tetanus – not communicable
  • Hepatitis B – One month before the appearance of Jaundice till the disappearance of HbsAg
  • Measles- 4 days before to 4 days after appearance of rash
  • Rubella – 7 days before to 7 days after the rash
  • Mumps -4-6 days before to 7 days after symptoms onset
  • Pertussis- 7 days before to 3 weeks after the onset of paroxysms
  • Diphtheria – Up to 4 weeks after disease onset
  • Meningococcal meningitis – till Meningococci are absent from nasal/throat swabs
  • Influenza – 1 to 2 days before and 1 to 2 days after onset of symptoms

questions.text: The given chest X-ray is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The given chest X-ray is suggestive of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The boot-shaped cardiac silhouette is seen due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on side appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or Figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented to the clinic with the following fetal presentation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of frank breech.

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Incomplete: Breech with extended legs, footling, knee presentation
  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs
Breech type Description Presenting part
Frank breech
(with extended legs)		 Thighs flexed on the trunk, legs extended at the knee joint. Buttocks and genitalia
Footling Both thighs and legs are partially extended Foot 
Knee  Thighs extended, Knee flexed Knee
Complete/flexed Both thighs and legs are flexed. Buttocks, genitalia, foot

questions.text: Identify the injury in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows abrasion.

An abrasion is the most superficial of injuries and, in the most restrictive of definitions, is one that does not penetrate the full thickness of the epidermis.

Thus the pure abrasion does not bleed, as blood vessels are confined to the dermis. Because of the corrugated nature of the dermal papillae, however, many abrasions enter the corium and bleeding commonly occurs.

questions.text: The life cycle of which of the following is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image given in question illustrates the life cycle of the Nipah virus, an RNA virus. Fruit bats serve as its natural host, and transmission occurs from bats and pigs to humans.

Nipah virus is an RNA virus from the family Paramyxoviridae and the genus Henipavirus. It is zoonotic, with fruit bats from the Pteropodidae family as its natural hosts. Transmission occurs from animals, such as bats and pigs, to humans, as well as between humans.Symptoms range from asymptomatic (subclinical) infection to acute respiratory illness and fatal encephalitis.

Currently, no treatment or vaccine exists for humans or animals, and supportive care is the main form of treatment for those infected. Nipah virus is also listed among the WHO's Blueprint priority diseases.

Other options:

Option A: Japanese encephalitis : Humans serve as dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus, which is transmitted through the bite of Culex mosquitoes, particularly Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui, commonly found in India. The transmission cycle involves birds, mosquitoes, and humans.The JE virus also infects various non-human hosts, such as pigs and birds like pond herons.

The main transmission cycles are:
(a) Pig → Mosquito → Pig
(b) Bird → Mosquito → Bird

Herons act as reservoir hosts, while pigs function as amplifier hosts. Control measures focus on mosquito control, relocating pig farms away from human habitation, and vaccinating pigs.

Option B: Zika virus is transmitted to humans primarily through the bite of an infected Aedes species mosquito (Ae. aegypti and Ae. albopictus).

Anyone who lives in or travels to a region with risk of Zika infection, and has not already been infected with Zika virus can get it from mosquito bites. Once a person has been infected, they are likely to be protected from future infections

A pregnant woman can pass Zika virus to her fetus during pregnancy. Zika is a cause of microcephaly and other severe fetal brain defects. Zika virus has also been found in breast milk. Possible Zika virus infections have been identified in breastfeeding babies, but Zika virus transmission through breast milk has not been confirmed.
Zika can be passed through sexual intercourse, even if the infected person does not have symptoms at the time.
To date, there have not been any confirmed blood transfusion transmission cases in the United States. There are reports of laboratory acquired Zika virus infections, although the route of transmission was not clearly established in all cases
 

Option D: Rabies is a fatal infection of the central nervous system transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal. It is caused by rhabdoviruses. These viruses are enveloped, rod or bullet shaped and contain single-stranded RNA. This virus attaches to the cells via its glycoprotein spikes and the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor acts as the cellular receptor.

questions.text: Which type of anal fistula is seen in this image?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the fistula traverses the internal sphincter and tracks down the space between the internal and external anal sphincters. Hence, it is an inter-sphincteric type of anal fistula. It is the most common anal fistula.

A fistula-in-ano is an epithelial-lined tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin. Patients usually complain of intermittent purulent discharge and pain. Anal fistulas can be simplex or complex fistulas.

  1. Simple fistulas- include a single tract, subcutaneous tract, and those that involve less than 30% of the external sphincter. They are easier to treat, and have lower chances of recurrence. 
  2. Complex fistulas- include fistulas involving more than 30% of the external sphincter, with multiple tracts, recurrent fistulas, and those associated with other predisposing factors, such as Crohn disease and radiation treatment.

Fistulas can also be classified into high or low-lying fistulas, based on their location with respect to the puborectalis muscle.

Related Pearl: Park's classification of fistula–in–ano

Perineal skin or perineum

20%

Dentate line

5%

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is shown in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The given image is a double contrast radiograph of barium meal. It is used to examine the lower half of the esophagus, stomach, and entire duodenum.

GI Imaging Preparations of barium Structures best visualized
Barium swallow Barium paste Esophagus
Barium meal 95% BaSO4 Stomach and duodenum
Barium meal follow-through 50% BaSO4 Small bowel
Barium enema 25% BaSO4 Large bowel

The below radiograph shows a barium follow-through study. It is useful in visualizing small bowel pathology and evaluating the function of the small bowel. It is inferior to enteroclysis enema where contrast is administered through a nasogastric tube.

The below radiograph is a double-contrast barium enema with a normal large bowel structure. The contrast is administered through a rectal tube and a series of radiographs are obtained.

questions.text: What is the following image of a barium swallow suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The image shows a markedly dilated esophagus and characteristic “bird's beak” appearance (distal narrowing), which is suggestive of achalasia cardia.

Achalasia cardia is caused due to the degeneration of the neurons in the myenteric plexus of the esophagus. This degeneration results in the failure of relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) on swallowing.

The patients present with a classic triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The dysphagia initially begins with liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods. As the food gets accumulated in the esophagus, patients may complain of halitosis. With further progression of the disease, the patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc.

The initial diagnosis is made by barium swallow or endoscopy, which shows the presence of dilated esophagus due to the constriction of the lower esophageal sphincter (bird-beak appearance). The gold standard test to confirm achalasia cardia is esophageal manometry.

questions.text: Which of the following situations does the red line in the following graph depict?
questions.solution:
The Red line in the graph represents a reaction with Noncompetitive inhibitor. The above graph is called 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot.

1/v0 is plotted versus 1/[S] and a straight line is obtained.This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors.

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged. Hence the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

questions.text: The characteristic inclusion in the cytoplasm of the cell seen below contains
questions.solution:
The image shows a Mott Cell containing multiple immunoglobulin globules in grapelike cytoplasmic droplets. Mott Cells may be seen in African Trypanosomiasis and in Multiple Myeloma

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the following image?

choices.text: Alcoholism predisposes to the development of this condition.
A mixed infection with aerobic and anaerobic bacteria is most common.

questions.solution:
The image above indicates that the patient has Fournier's gangrene, and despite best therapy, mortality rates are 50%. 

Concurrent illnesses like diabetes mellitus and alcoholism, predispose patients to Fournier's gangrene. 

The sequence of events are as follows: A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene

The testis is usually not affected.

It is a surgical emergency.

questions.text: A woman came with a 4 x 3 cm lump over the left breast. On examination, the breast appears as shown below. Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes are palpable with fixed axillary nodes on the right side. What is the most appropriate tumor staging?
questions.solution:
TNM staging in the given scenario is T4b N3c M1. 

  • Tumour of any size with overlying skin involvement (Peau d'orange appearance) - T4b
  • Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph node involvement - N3c
  • Involvement of any contralateral lymph nodes indicates distant metastasis - M1

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of carcinoma breast

Tumor (T) Description
Tis Ductal carcinoma in situ / Paget's disease
T1

≤2 cm in greatest dimension

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – inflammatory breast carcinoma(typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
Metastasis absent M0
Metastasis present M1

  

Stages       T , N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0
Stage IA T1N0 M0
Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0
Stage IIA T0,1N1 (or) T2N0 M0
Stage IIB T2N1 (or) T3N0 M0
Stage IIIA T0,1,2,3N2 (or) T3N1 M0
Stage IIIB T4 N0,1,2 M0
Stage IIIC

Any T, N3

 M0
Stage IV

Any T, Any N

 M1

#Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of chest wall.

*Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage IIIB) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered as a benign condition and not included under Tis.

questions.text: Identify the organisation that has the given logo.

choices.text: National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme

questions.solution:
The given image is the emblem of the National Leprosy Eradication Programme(NLEP)

Characteristics of NLEP emblem :

  • The lotus in the NLEP Emblem symbolizes beauty and purity.
  • A partially affected thumb; a normal fore-finger and the shape of house symbolize that leprosy can be cured and a patient with leprosy can be a useful member of the society.
  • The rising sun symbolizes hope and optimism.
  • The Emblem captures the spirit of hope and positivity in the eradication of Leprosy.

The National Leprosy Eradication Programme is a centrally sponsored Health Scheme of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Govt. of India.

Leprosy work is not merely medical relief; it is transforming frustration of life into joy of dedication, personal ambition into selfless service- Mahatma Gandhi.

Option 1) NVBDCP

Option 2) DOTS (RNTCP)

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a female condom. It consists of a pouch made of polyurethane which is 17 cm in length with flexible ring at each end. The inner ring at the closed end is smaller than the outer ring.

The inner ring is inserted at the apex of the vagina and the outer ring remains outside. It covers the cervix, entire vagina, and external genitalia. Hence, it provides protection against HIV and STDs. It has a failure rate of 5–15 per 100 woman-years, which is higher than that of a male condom.

questions.text: The test kit shown in the image below works on the principle of:
questions.solution:
The above image shows a HbsAg card test kit which works on the principle of immunochromatography.

The immunochromatographic membrane is used for antigen detection, while a nitrocellulose membrane is used to absorb the antigen from a specimen. A coloured reaction appears directly on the membrane with the sequential addition of conjugate followed by the substrate. In some cases, the antigen is captured by a bound antibody directed against the antigen. These assays have the advantage of being rapid and also frequently include a built-in internal control.

questions.text: Nerve supply of the area marked by arrow in the image is:
questions.solution: The area marked in the image is supplied by radial nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones act through the receptor shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The receptor in the given image uses tyrosine kinase signaling. Insulin acts through this receptor to exert its functions.

Other hormones acting via tyrosine kinase signaling: 

  • Growth hormone
  • Growth factors like VEGF, PDGF, FGF, NGF
  • Prolactin
  • Leptin

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin

Acetylcholine (M2, M4)

GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)

Note: Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the condition shown in the image below?

choices.text: Malunion can happen if this condition is not treated
The patient may be able to walk
Avascular necrosis is the most common complication
Shortening of limb is less than 1 inch

questions.solution:
The radiograph shows a fracture neck of the femur. Non-union is a complication of this fracture, not malunion. 

Malunion is a complication of inter-trochanteric fractures.

Complications of fracture neck of the femur are:

  • Avascular necrosis (most common)
  • Non-union
  • Osteonecrosis of the femoral head may lead to secondary osteoarthritis after many years

Option B: In impacted fracture neck of femur, the patient may be able to walk.

Option D: Shortening of the limb is less than 1 inch in fracture neck of femur.

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of hip
  • Body of talus in fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of scaphoid in fracture through the waist of the scaphoid

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen in the fracture of neck of talus. Presence of this sign indicates that blood supply to the talus is adequate.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought with the following finding. His mother says that he had banged his leg against a chair yesterday. He has had similar episodes in the past but they were never this severe. What lab values will you likely find in this boy?

choices.text: Normal bleeding time, prolonged PT, prolonged aPTT
Normal bleeding time, prolonged PT,  normal aPTT
Prolonged bleeding time, normal PT, prolonged aPTT
Normal bleeding time, normal PT, prolonged aPTT

questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, recurrent hemarthrosis in a male child is suggestive of hemophilia. Normal bleeding time, normal PT, prolonged aPTT is seen in hemophilia A and B.

Hemophilia A has decreased factor VIII activity and hemophilia B has decreased factor IX activity.

Note: Prolonged bleeding time, normal PT, prolonged aPTT is seen in von Willebrand disease.

Related Pearl: Coagulation Pathways and its Abnormalities

Test results Inherited causes Acquired causes
Prolonged PT (extrinsic pathway factors) Factor VII deficiency  Mild vitamin K deficiency, liver disease, warfarin
Prolonged aPTT (intrinsic pathway factors)

Factors VIII, IX, XI deficiency

Factor XII, prekallikrein, or HMW kininogen deficiency

von Willebrand disease

 Heparin, lupus anticoagulant, acquired von Willebrand disease
Prolonged PT +prolonged aPTT (common pathway factors) Prothrombin (II), fibrinogen (I), factors V and factor X deficiencies

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Severe liver disease

Severe vitamin K deficiency

Direct thrombin inhibitor-argatroban, dabigatran

Direct factor Xa inhibitor-rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban

Fondaparinux

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Auvard speculum. It retracts the posterior vaginal wall during vaginal hysterectomy and is self retractory due to the circular structure on its handle which is heavy.

The image given below shows Sim's speculum.

The image given below shows Cusco's self retaining bivalved speculum.

questions.text: What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Becker's naevus.

It is an epidermal melanocytic naevus with aggregation of melanocyte clusters in the epidermis. It is often hairy. The onset is around adolescence when there is an increased sensitivity to androgens especially in the distribution of outer arms, scapular area and chest.

A triad of features can be seen:

  1. Hyperpigmentation
  2. Hypertrichosis
  3. Acne

Option A: Mongolian spots are slate blue areas in the lumbosacral region that spontaneously regress before puberty.

Option B: Naevus of Ito is unilateral hyperpigmentation in the acromioclavicular distribution. It is not known to have hypertrichosis or acne.

Option C: Congenital melanocytic nevi are common moles that become raised and have a cerebriform appearance and can be hairy. They can occur anywhere.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presented to the clinic with the lesions shown below. Which of the following conditions is/are associated with this lesion?
  1. Chronic liver disease
  2. Pregnancy
  3. Scleroderma
  4. Thyrotoxicosis
  5. Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome
questions.solution:
The lesions shown in the image are spider naevi (nevus araneus). They are seen in:

  • Estrogen excess states such as pregnancy and OCP use
  • Chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease
  • Thyrotoxicosis

They are vascular lesions characterized by the tortuous dilatation of arterioles just underneath the skin. On applying and releasing pressure over the lesion they typically fill from the centre outward.
